Open-source container orchestration that automates deployment, scaling, and management of containerized apps across a cluster. Works with multiple container runtimes (e.g., containerd).
Scaling & high availability; self-healing; automated rollouts/rollbacks; service discovery & load balancing; storage orchestration; config/secrets; portable across clouds.
A set of machines managed together by Kubernetes to run containerized workloads.
A single machine in the cluster. Control-plane nodes run management components; worker nodes run application Pods.
A packaged process built from an image (your app + its dependencies) that runs in isolation.
Smallest deployable unit. Wraps one or more containers that share the same network IP and volumes; ephemeral; unit of scheduling and scaling.
Front door for all Kubernetes requests. Validates and persists objects to the database (etcd); serves the Kubernetes API over HTTPS.
The cluster database. Stores Kubernetes objects (specs and status), such as Pods, Deployments, Services, ConfigMaps, Secrets, RBAC, etc. Not your app's user data.
Assigns newly created (unscheduled) Pods to suitable worker nodes based on resource availability and policies.
Runs controllers that reconcile desired state vs current state (e.g., keep N replicas, recreate failed Pods, manage Jobs).
Agent on each worker node. Starts/stops containers to satisfy Pod specs, runs health probes, and reports status back to the API Server.
Software that runs containers (e.g., containerd or CRI-O). Pulls images and executes containers for Pods.
Programs node-level network rules so Services can load-balance traffic to the current Pod IPs.
Higher-level controller that manages ReplicaSets/Pods for stateless apps and supports rolling updates & rollbacks.
Ensures a specified number of identical Pods are running; created and managed by a Deployment in most cases.
Controller for stateful apps; gives Pods stable identities and ordered, predictable rollouts/scaling.
Stable virtual IP/DNS that routes to a group of Pods selected by labels; types: ClusterIP, NodePort, LoadBalancer.
HTTP/HTTPS routing rules that expose Services to external clients via hostnames/paths and TLS.
ConfigMap: non-sensitive key-values. Secret: sensitive data (passwords/tokens/keys). Both can be mounted as files or injected as env vars.
Pod volumes provide storage. PV: cluster storage resource; PVC: request for storage; StorageClass: how PVs are provisioned; Pods mount PVCs for persistence.
You submit YAML describing desired state; Kubernetes stores it and continuously works to make the actual state match it.
Continuous observe → compare → act cycle run by controllers to keep current state aligned with desired state.
Local Kubernetes for development/learning. Provides a single-node cluster with add-ons; alternatives: kind, microk8s.
CLI to interact with the API Server: apply manifests, list and inspect resources, get logs, exec, etc.
Provision a managed control plane and node pools on Google Cloud, then use kubectl (via gcloud) to deploy workloads.
Deployments (mysql, phpmyadmin), Services (internal for DB, external for UI), Secret (DB creds), ConfigMap (DB URL), optional PV/PVC for persistence.
